Award.AwardTitle: Targeted Infusion: Strengthening Forensic Science Undergraduates Research and Instruction Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: In order for the institution to continue to meet the needs of its students in the Biology department, the targeted infusion project of Fort Valley State University has as its goal to infuse undergraduate research and instruction into the forensic science curriculum. Forensic science is a rapidly expanding and interdisciplinary science that has already captured the attention of many undergraduate STEM majors. The goal of this project is to foster that enthusiasm while also strengthening the existing NSF-funded HBCU UP STEM program at FVSU. A collection of strategies will be employed to achieve this goal. They include, but are not limited to: the incorporation of inquiry based lectures and labs in forensic sciences, establishment of a forensic science core research laboratory, undergraduate research opportunities, high school teacher workshops and faculty development. Ultimately, the activities proposed will not only expose students to the breadth of concepts related to forensic science and its application to real world problems, but will also improve their capacities to compete for highly coveted graduate programs at major research intensive institutions. Overall, the forensic science program at FVSU will impact over 200 students and faculty each year, thereby significantly contributing to the potential pool of qualified STEM graduates from diverse backgrounds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Title: Targeted Infusion: Strengthening Forensic  Science
Undergraduates Research and Instruction Program.

Intellectual Merit: Is to incorporate inquiry based lectures and labs in forensic science, establish a forensic science core research
laboratory, and provide research opportunities to undergraduate students, organize seminars by invited speaker and faculty development. The instruction and curriculum of forensic science program  has been enhanced by infusing a strong DNA, RNA-PCR based Amplification, Analysis of Drugs and poisons – chemical tests to Presumptive Blood Test for crime scene investigation, as well as integrating new technology into teaching and undergraduate research. Other activities include a
seminar series, professional and career development workshops, GRE preparation classes and field trips to various labs.

Broader Impacts: Undergraduate underrepresented minority groups training in the forensic science (27 undergraduates), participation and presentation at scientific meeting (38 presentations at 7 different meetings at Annual Research Day to Capitol Hill as well as at national and international meetings), and placement in the graduate/professional school. Inquiry based two courses were redesigned by support with this grant allowed 108 students to conduct the innovative lab experiments during their class work. Highlights of student’s achievements in the labs and undergraduate research experience were disseminated in nine articles on FVSU website.
